experiments.name: 001_baseline
experiments.notes: Established baseline using bucket-of-chump pre-optimized dataset. This is the best publicly available solution. Score: 70.647327, Target: 68.919154, Gap: 1.728173 (2.45% improvement needed). Score distribution by N range: N=1-50: 19.04, N=51-100: 17.63, N=101-150: 17.14, N=151-200: 16.84. Top N values with highest score contribution are small N (N=1-10) which contribute most per-N.

data_findings.finding: Competition is 2D packing optimization: pack N Christmas trees (N=1-200) into smallest square bounding box. Score = sum(side^2/N) for all N. Lower is better. Target: 68.919154

Key approaches: (1) bbox3 C++ optimizer with simulated annealing, (2) fix_direction rotation optimization, (3) Pre-optimized CSV datasets. Kernels use datasets like 'bucket-of-chump' and 'santa-2025-csv' as starting points.

Discussion topics suggest: (1) Asymmetric solutions may beat symmetric ones (34 votes), (2) Symmetric solutions can be optimal for some N (42 votes), (3) Tessellations for efficient packing, (4) SA micro-optimization has diminishing returns
Best public solution (bucket-of-chump) scores 70.647, target is 68.919. Gap of 1.73 points needed. Score distribution: N=1-50: 19.04, N=51-100: 17.63, N=101-150: 17.14, N=151-200: 16.84

web_research.query: What are the best algorithms for 2D irregular polygon packing optimization problems?
web_research.finding: Two‑dimensional irregular‑polygon packing is a highly combinatorial problem, so the most successful approaches today are **meta‑heuristic and hybrid heuristics** that balance solution quality with tractable run‑time.  A broad survey of the field notes that genetic algorithms (GAs) are the work‑horse technique, often combined with problem‑specific operators or a linear‑programming (LP) sub‑solver to handle geometric constraints ([Frontiers](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fmech.2022.966691/full)).  Variants such as a GA‑LP hybrid have been shown to outperform pure GA or pure LP on benchmark strip‑packing instances ([MDPI](https://www.mdpi.com/2076-3417/13/22/12474)).  Other meta‑heuristics that repeatedly appear in the literature include **simulated annealing, tabu search, ant‑colony optimisation and particle‑swarm optimisation**, each adapted to the irregular‑shape context ([Springer](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1023/A:1012590107280)).  Complementary constructive
